metadata.sermon_start_end: The performance artist Laurie Anderson, whose new show is opening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music next week, is a reader of the Bible and the literary classics. [...] This very day he might be calling you to perform a miracle of love and humility that you never thought you were capable of. And you know what? It will make you laugh. It will be both fun and funny. “Rejoice in the Lord always; again I will say, Rejoice” (Phil. 4:4). AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses on the Christ-hymn of Philippians 2. However, it struggles to identify what is unique to THIS text versus general Christological truths. The preacher uses the text as a springboard for a 'Big Idea' rather than mining the specific linguistic nuances of the pericope's unique contribution to the canon.
quotes: In the beginning of our passage, Paul says...
not in a million years could any human being come up with the Big Idea that we have in this passage
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify what Philippians 2:5-8 says that cannot be found in the Gospels or other epistles—specifically the tension between 'morphe' (form) and 'schema' (appearance) which Dekker's theses imply requires deeper specificity.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic attempt at exposition regarding the Roman context of crucifixion and the status of a slave. However, the preacher relies on a modern pop-culture foil (Laurie Anderson) more than the theological-historical context of the Philippian congregation. The mention of 'morphe' is superficial.
quotes: Christ was in the form (morphe-) of God … he took the form (morphe-) of a slave (doulos).
Everybody in Paul’s time had seen one [a crucifixion]. People were put on crosses by the side of the road; you couldn’t miss them.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exegesis of what 'equality with God' meant in a Roman imperial context where Caesar claimed such status, rather than comparing it to Bill Gates or Donald Trump.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is often anecdotal or psychological. While it mentions school shootings and church carpets, it tends toward moralism ('rewrite your own story') which Dekker warns against if it becomes a general truth rather than a text-driven necessity.
quotes: I remember to this day when a committee of ladies in one church put a blue carpet in the chancel where it used to be red.
What steps can you take to rewrite your own story?
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid the shift to 'self-help' language ('rewrite your own story'). The application should flow from the text's demand for the 'mind of Christ' in the specific communal life of the congregation.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon moves back and forth between the text and the contemporary world reasonably well. It avoids a strict 'block' structure, though the transition from the Laurie Anderson song to the theology of the Cross feels somewhat forced.
quotes: Let’s look back at Laurie Anderson. She sings, 'I’d rewrite the book of love.' That’s the most interesting part of her song.
So the ugly people are going to get the money after all. You and I are the 'ugly people'...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the contemporary examples (like the kidney donors) serve the text's logic rather than distracting from it.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes misery (human selfishness, even in good deeds) and redemption (Christ's substitution). Gratitude is present but leans slightly toward a 'miracle of love' the hearer must perform.
quotes: Even the good things I do, I do for selfish reasons...
Jesus took all of that onto himself when he died a godless death.
The ugly people put Jesus on the Cross, but he never stopped loving us
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Anchor the 'gratitude' section more firmly in the Spirit's work rather than the hearer's 'miracle of love'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon touches on the 'godless death' and being 'prisoners of our worst selves,' but it lacks the sharp edge of Dekker's 'two ways.' The ending is quite 'light' and optimistic, potentially softening the seriousness of being lost.
quotes: The Cross reveals to us just how godless we really were.
It will make you laugh. It will be both fun and funny.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The gravity of 'destruction' (the broad way) mentioned in Dekker's Thesis 6 is missing. The sermon needs to address the consequence of rejecting the 'mind of Christ'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the sermon's strongest point. Christ is clearly the telos. The preacher maintains the doctrine of the two natures and emphasizes that salvation is outside of man.
quotes: He stepped into our place and lived out the story the way it was supposed to be lived...
Man has no life in himself, it is Christ who is his life. [Paraphrased by: 'we do not have to be prisoners of our worst selves anymore']
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Maintain the focus on Christ's divinity as the source of the 'Big Idea' without diluting it into a 'funny' or 'fun' experience at the end.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1550 words, the sermon likely lasts 15-16 minutes. According to Dekker's Thesis 8, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical and dogmatic 'breadth' to reach the 20-minute threshold required for substantive proclamation.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is Christocentric but falls short of Dekker's standards regarding length and the 'two ways.' It relies heavily on a pop-culture foil that, while engaging, risks turning the specific Word of God into a 'Big Idea' among others. The application tends toward the psychological and moralistic ('rewrite your story') rather than the radical actualization of the text.
strengths: Strong emphasis on the substitutionary work of Christ.
Clear articulation of human misery and the selfishness of 'good' works.
Effective use of the 'form of a slave' imagery to explain the humiliation of Christ.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) to achieve necessary depth.
The ending is overly optimistic ('fun and funny'), undermining the gravity of the 'two ways'.
The application becomes individualistic and psychological toward the conclusion.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a partially successful sermon that captures the 'One Lord' well, but lacks the 'breadth' and the 'seriousness of the two ways' required by Dekker. It risks becoming a speech about a 'Big Idea' rather than a specific actualization of the Word.
